lines.Vitus: "You mentioned before that the bathhouse was your favourite place in a city, right?"

lines.Herclaus: "That I did!"

lines.Vitus: "I'm sorry you haven't had much time to visit this one."

lines.Herclaus: "Leisure comes later, lad."
"We had a greater cause that required our attention."

lines.Volesus: "And we certainly gained more attention than we bargained for."

lines.Herclaus: "That is often how it goes."

"We reap the consequences of our actions,
and there's rarely room for foresight."
"What matters is how we react to whatever comes our way, and when we do so."

lines.Volesus: "Alright."
"But both of you realise that the ordeal with the general isn't over, right?"

lines.Herclaus: "I'm not sure what you mean."
"We won his battle that he could not win... along with the hearts and the cooperation of his men."

lines.Volesus: "Right."
"But he was still a nobleman."

lines.Herclaus: "It doesn't matter how much monera you have in your pockets if you bring dishonour to your men and country."

lines.Volesus: "...It does when the country you live in is an oligarchy."
"And when there are different kinds of currencies than monera."
"Relationships... and legacies, for instance."
"Old families have many connections and many opportunities to take revenge."

lines.Herclaus: "If men choose not to fight for their fellow man, then a country is already lost."
"I have more faith that any strong country will choose to thrive rather than wilt away at the behest of a few weak men."

lines.Volesus: "Herclaus..."
"I just wanted to ask."
"How do you think somebody becomes a ruler in the first place?"

lines.Herclaus: "Oh!"
"Well, they have the most men supporting them."
"A leader is nothing without his men.

lines.Volesus: "Right."
"And how do you think people tend to get that support?"

lines.Herclaus: "Through guile and the strength of their deeds, of course."
"So sometimes, this is true, and a great man builds a great country."

lines.Volesus:
"And in this case, a leader will have a child
or select an heir to replace him."

lines.Herclaus: "Yes, I already know this."

lines.Volesus: "But over the passage of generations, these rulers can lose touch with the initial hardships that their predecessors had to overcome."
"And natural leaders can turn into leadership through birthright, or through favour."

lines.Vitus: "And social impressions can become more important than... well, actions."

lines.Volesus: "...or access to resources, or standards of living."

lines.Herclaus: "I wouldn't worry about such things."
"Weak rulers always get replaced with successful ones."
"The same applies to countries."
"But the people endure."

lines.Volesus: "Then, I have a quick question for you, Herclaus. "
"What's your rough estimation for the population size of an empire?"

lines.Herclaus: "Well, that's easy!"
""I'm not so bad at mathematics, you know—despite my reputation."
"How about... fifty thousand men, roughly."
"That's more than sizeable for the most mighty empire."

lines.Volesus: "Sixty-seven million."
"That's the official census of our empire from the prior decade."

lines.Herclaus: "What?!"
"But... nothing can be that big."

lines.Volesus: "Despite being a mess of a leader, that general wasn't lying when he told you that the world has changed since you last saw it."
"He knew the numbers."
"I doubt his true intentions were to win any battles in Irinipolis."
"He just wanted to slow the enemy down on this front."
"It's very possible that the decision wasn't even his own."
"But it was clear that he believed fully in those tactics."

lines.Herclaus: "Perhaps I don't understand the scope of what we're dealing with, after all."
"But what is done is done."
"I could not live as a coward, and I certainly could not die as one."

lines.Vitus: "Because I find myself feeling the same way the more time I spend with you."
"Decisions come easier, and I find it harder to regret my choices."

lines.Volesus: "I feel the same as well."
"...which is part of what makes you so dangerous, isn't it?"

lines.Herclaus: "...Are you calling me your enemy?"

lines.Volesus: "Quite the contrary."
"You make things bearable in situations where we risk our lives."
"You almost make it feel romantic."
"Isn't that a frightful mindset for a war?"

lines.Herclaus: "Well, of course it is."

lines.Volesus: "But it is that very feeling that inspires young men to act."
"Did you know that about yourself?"

lines: ("Herclaus is touching his horns again, as if lost in thought.")

lines.Herclaus: "I'm just trying to piece together if I'm being complimented or insulted."

lines.Volesus: "It's more of a neutral observation."
"Knowing when to have courage and when to be scared is a powerful survival tool."
"But it's much easier to be scared than it is to be brave."

lines.Herclaus: "Well, thank you."
"But all of this thinking is making me tired again."

lines.Vitus: "Then why don't we just soak, not think for a while."
"If anybody's earned that for a moment, it's you."

lines.Herclaus: "Now that's more like it!"
"...But let's not be idle for too long. The weather tonight is great for sparring."

lines.Volesus: "...No more exercise."
